Letters
Carbon copies
Denver (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the top right hand side of the first page handwritten in pencil is "333" circled

Typed letter from JCRS to Mr. B Thomashefsky explaning how hard it is to excent the stay of patients because they have so many patients who are waiting to get in. The letter states that Mr. Krawitz is one of the oldest patients and his condition has not shown any signs of improvement or failing health. Therefore the Sanatorium cannot do much else for him as they do not take on cases of of those who are incurable or chronic because they would not be able to help as many people. The letter then notifies Mr. Thomashefsky of the extention granted to Mr. Krawitz.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society Records, Patient Records

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed letter from JCRS to Hartford Ladies Consumptives' Relief Society, dated December 18, 1906. The letter acknowledges the arrival of Mr. Harry Johnson, and notes that he has filled out an application and is awaiting his turn to enter the sanatorium. The letter then admonishes the Hartford society for sending Mr. Johnson to Denver with no resources, and explains that Mr. Johnson was told his board will be paid by the Hartford society for as long as his wait to enter the sanatorium. Patient Records
Letters
Denver (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed letter from JCRS to Mr. Jacob Blum. The letter is concerning the inquiry Mr. Blum sent concerning Mr. Max Siegle's condition. The letter statest that Mr. Siegle suffered from a tubucular rib yet the Sanatorium is not able to perform the needed major operation so he will have to go to another hospital. The letter states that Mr. Siegle's chances for recovery are doubtful and it seems best that he return to his family and friends. Therefore at the end of six months Mr. Siegle will be discharged because his conditions will not improve. The letter is not signed but ''Secretary'' is typed on the bottom.
